newsitem.title: USA: Argentina bonds surge, as Bulgarian Bradies suffer.
newsitem.headline: Argentina bonds surge, as Bulgarian Bradies suffer.

text.p: Argentine Brady bonds surged on Tuesday amid local optimism and news of fresh Eurobonds, while Bulgarian paper slumped after the International Monetary Fund postponed a loan disbursement.
One emerging market debt trader cited strong local interest in Buenos Aires for Argentine paper, prompting Argentine FRBs to gain 1-1/4 for a bid price of 78-7/8.
"It seems the local guys are more comfortable with the risk today," the trader said.
Players also seemed comforted by Argentina's launching of two 350 million mark Eurobond issues, of seven and 20-year maturities, via lead manager CSFB-Effectenbank.
"Argentina got a good bounce," said another Brady bond debt trader at a U.S. investment bank. "We saw some selling of Bulgaria for Venezuela or Argentina."
Venezuelan DCBs outperformed Tuesday, gaining 5/8 to 76 cents on the dollar.
The main loser was Bulgaria, which saw its Brady prices drop sharply after the IMF said it would put off paying out a second $115 million tranche until October at the earliest.
Bulgarian IABs came off their lows in the U.S. afternoon, but still closed off 2-5/8 at 42-3/8.
The overall Brady market trailed U.S. Treasuries higher though lagged T-bond prices amid lingering concerns that U.S. interest rates are heading higher.
"The market is going to remain vulnerable to higher US rates," said Joyce Chang, managing director at Merrill Lynch.
The surge in oil prices after the recent escalation of tensions in Iraq may carry over to the emerging debt market, Chang said.

"There may be more certainty about how the oil-exporting countries fare amid higher U.S. rates," Chang said. "That's quite positive for a number of countries -- Algeria, Ecuador Mexico, Nigeria and Venezuela."
Philippine paper performed solidly in the wake of the country's plan to issue $2.0 billion of Eurobonds in buy back Brady debt.
